page.title: 02Landscape
page.content: The main feature is the valley of the river Kent running north to south through the survey area. At a height of about 150m. above sea level, the valley is typically 100-150m. below the surrounding upland. It is widest and flattest in the north of the area where there once existed a glacial lake, now largely reclaimed Evidence of glaciation is to be seen in the abundance of smooth mounds of glacial drift, both on the edges of the valley floor and on the higher ground on either side, especially in the vicinity of Skeggles Water in the east of the area. Geologically, the area is made up of slates and grits of the Silurian period. The many small streams flow in to the Kent but the drainage is poor in the area of Skeggles Water.
